p: The analysis also involved creating analytic memos to document the development of the team’s understanding of women’s experiences of living with both PND and HIV and to identify emergent patterns and relationships between codes, which assisted in connecting the data [ 26, 27]. The first author then created matrices to identify and analyze similarities and differences between participants for key themes [ 28]. Lastly, using narrative analysis, the first author wrote an HIV diagnosis narrative based on the participant ‘Ruth.’ Because women’s stories often began with their HIV-diagnosis, a life-changing event, the narrative structure assisted in analysis by establishing chronology [ 24, 29, 30]. We use the illustrative case of Ruth to highlight processes over time within one woman’s experience, as a complement to thematic summaries and quotes.
